Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates wearing crown of upper and lower Egypt, hair in a side knot. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white (gypsum?) coating with red paint on outer crown. Red-brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Gutch dated this piece to between 150BC and 250AD (Gutch in Hogarth 1899, pl. 12, no. 134). Similar pieces have been dated to the mid 2nd century BC (Fischer 1994, pl. 67. no. 637) and to the Roman period (Dunand 1990, 68, no.122). Close parallels from Tell Atrib were found in 3rd to early 2nd century BC context (Szymańska 2005, nos 54, 76). Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.012) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 89-90, no. 134, pl. XII, no. 134)
